Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Improved Learning for Undergraduate Engineering Programs Using Finite Element Learning Modules

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this project is to develop a set of active-learning, finite element analysis based course modules with commercial software for use in a variety of undergraduate courses at a diverse set of nine universities across the nation. The effectiveness of the modules is being assessed by faculty and students with student learning experience progression, learning styles, and personality types being taken into account. The project advances active-learning techniques in undergraduate engineering education utilizing the finite element method for modeling and analysis of complex engineering problems in eight areas. The project provides a quantitative measure of how well the modules enhance learning equitably across different student demographic variables. The project results are disseminated in various ways, such as via an internet website and faculty workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There were two major goals of this project: 1) to use active-learning techniques, particularly self-paced tutorials, to increase learning in broader areas of undergraduate courses and 2) to provide undergraduate engineering students with basic knowledge in finite element analysis (FEA) theory, along with an ability to apply commercial finite element software to solve typical engineering problems. Investigators at six different universities were supported to develop active learning modules (ALM) for incorporating finite element analysis in existing undergraduate enigneering courses. The participating universities were University of the Pacific (Stockton, CA), California State Polytechnic Institute (Pomona, CA), Tuskegee University (Tuskegee, AL), US Air Force Academy (Colorado Springs, CO), University of New Haven (West Haven, CT), and Washington State University (Pullman, WA). The University of Texas at Austin coordinated development and maintenance of the online repository for pre/post-test evaluation results and supervised analysis of evaluation results.

The module developers were encouraged to design their modules with the end learning objectives in mind: (1) experiment with FEA theory; (2) apply complex engineering concepts using computer models of engineering problems; (3) examine typical steps in building a finite element model, such as selecting element type, loads, and boundary conditions; and (4) practice validating approximate finite element results with analytical solutions. Each of the FE learning modules uses a well-known commercial FEA software package. A total of 15 modules was created.

Over five years, the modules were administered to over 750 students at the six participating colleges and universities. Each of the modules was assessed for effectiveness in accomplishing the learning objectives. Pre- and post-tests were administered and statistically analyzed. Demographic and learning styles data were also collected. In addition to this quantitative analysis, we also summarized verbal student feedback for professors implementing these modules. The student survey results were shared with the researchers to give them feedback for improving their learning modules.

The average improvement in student learning over all module administrations was 41.7%. Additionally, some students
applied their understanding of finite element analysis (FEA) in other classes, such  as  their senior design projects.

The modules are available through our open access portal at http://sites.google.com/site/finiteelementlearning/home. This web site contains all modules developed in all phases of this project. A link to the modules has also been publicized at other web sites such as The National Science Digital Library, Open Education Consortium and other sites that accept links for this type of material.


Last Modified: 03/06/2016
Modified by: Richard H Crawford
